localizedDescriptions.en: Interaction, contact or care event between a subject of care and healthcare provider(s).
Framework for consistent modelling of observations and measurements about essential physiological functions.
A measurement of the body temperature, which is a surrogate for the core body temperature of the individual.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The measured temperature.
Blood oxygen and related measurements, measured by pulse oximetry or pulse CO-oximetry.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The saturation of oxygen in the peripheral blood, measured via pulse oximetry.

annotations.comment: SpO₂ is defined as the percentage of oxyhaemoglobin (HbO₂) to the total concentration of haemoglobin (HbO₂ + deoxyhaemoglobin) in peripheral blood.

localizedDescriptions.en: The local measurement of arterial blood pressure which is a surrogate for arterial pressure in the systemic circulation.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Peak systemic arterial blood pressure  - measured in systolic or contraction phase of the heart cycle.
Minimum systemic arterial blood pressure - measured in the diastolic or relaxation phase of the heart cycle.

annotations.comment: Most commonly, use of the term 'blood pressure' refers to measurement of brachial artery pressure in the upper arm.

localizedDescriptions.en: The rate and associated attributes for a pulse or heart beat.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The rate of the pulse or heart beat, measured in beats per minute.
The characteristics of spontaneous breathing by an individual.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The frequency of spontaneous breathing.
Height, or body length, is measured from crown of head to sole of foot.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The length of the body from crown of head to sole of foot.

annotations.comment: Height is measured with the individual in a standing position and body length in a recumbent position.

localizedDescriptions.en: Measurement of the body weight of an individual.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The weight of the individual.
Calculated measurement which compares a person's weight and height.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Index describing ratio of weight to height.

annotations.comment: Body Mass Index is a calculated ratio describing how an individual's body weight relates to the weight that is regarded as normal, or desirable, for the individual's height.

localizedDescriptions.en: Measurement of the time taken for color to return to an external capillary bed after pressure is applied to cause blanching.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The measured time taken for color to return after blanching.

annotations.comment: Sometimes expressed as 'capillary return'.

localizedDescriptions.en: The result, including findings and the laboratory's interpretation, of an investigation performed on specimens collected from an individual or related to that individual.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Name of the laboratory investigation performed on the specimen(s).

annotations.comment: A test result may be for a single analyte, or a group of items, including panel tests. It is strongly recommended that 'Test name' be coded with a terminology, for example LOINC or SNOMED CT. For example: 'Glucose', 'Urea and Electrolytes', 'Swab', 'Cortisol (am)', 'Potassium in perspiration' or 'Melanoma histopathology'. The name may sometimes include specimen type and patient state, for example 'Fasting blood glucose' or include other information, as 'Potassium (PNA blood gas)'.

localizedDescriptions.en: The result of a laboratory test for a single analyte value.
The value of the analyte result.

annotations.comment: For example '7.3 mmol/l', 'Raised'. The 'Any' data type will need to be constrained to an appropriate data type in a specialisation, a template or at run-time to reflect the actual analyte result. The Quantity data type has reference model attributes that include flags for normal/abnormal, reference ranges and approximations - see https://specifications.openehr.org/releases/RM/latest/data_types.html#_dv_quantity_class for more details.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description of the key findings.

annotations.comment: For example: 'Pattern suggests significant renal impairment'. The content of the conclusion will vary, depending on the investigation performed. This conclusion should be aligned with the coded 'Test diagnosis'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Details about a single identified health condition, injury, disability or any other issue which impacts on the physical, mental and/or social well-being of an individual.

children.name: Chief Complaint

localizedDescriptions.en: Identification of the problem or diagnosis, by name.

children.aqlPath: /content[openEHR-EHR-EVALUATION.problem_diagnosis.v1 and name/value='Chief Complaints']/data[at0001]/items[at0002 and name/value='Chief Complaint']/value

annotations.comment: Coding of the name of the problem or diagnosis with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

Clear delineation between the scope of a problem versus a diagnosis is not easy to achieve in practice. For the purposes of clinical documentation with this archetype, problem and diagnosis are regarded as a continuum, with increasing levels of detail and supportive evidence usually providing weight towards the label of 'diagnosis'.

localizedDescriptions.en: The subjective clinical history of the subject of care as recorded directly by the subject, or reported to a clinician by the subject or a carer.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Narrative description of the story or clinical history for the subject of care.
Findings observed during the physical examination of a subject of care.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Narrative description of the overall findings observed during a physical examination of a patient.

annotations.comment: May be used to record a narrative summary of the complete clinical examination or key aspects of clinical examination findings, which will be supported by structured data. Details of specific structured findings can be included using CLUSTER archetypes in the 'Examination Detail' slot. This data element may be used to capture legacy data that is not available in a structured format.

localizedDescriptions.en: Details about a single identified health condition, injury, disability or any other issue which impacts on the physical, mental and/or social well-being of an individual.
Identification of the problem or diagnosis, by name.

annotations.comment: Coding of the name of the problem or diagnosis with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the problem or diagnosis not captured in other fields.

annotations.comment: Clear delineation between the scope of a problem versus a diagnosis is not easy to achieve in practice. For the purposes of clinical documentation with this archetype, problem and diagnosis are regarded as a continuum, with increasing levels of detail and supportive evidence usually providing weight towards the label of 'diagnosis'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Reported observation of a physical or mental disturbance in an individual.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The name of the reported symptom or sign.

annotations.comment: Symptom name should be coded with a terminology, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Request for a health-related service or activity to be delivered by a clinician, organisation or agency.
Current Activity.
The name of the single service or activity requested.

annotations.comment: Coding of the 'Service name' with a coding system is desirable, if available. For example: 'referral' to an endocrinologist for diabetes management.

localizedDescriptions.en: Request for a health-related service or activity to be delivered by a clinician, organisation or agency.
Current Activity.
The name of the single service or activity requested.

annotations.comment: Coding of the 'Service name' with a coding system is desirable, if available. For example: 'referral' to an endocrinologist for diabetes management.

localizedDescriptions.en: Request for a health-related service or activity to be delivered by a clinician, organisation or agency.
Current Activity.
The name of the single service or activity requested.

annotations.comment: Coding of the 'Service name' with a coding system is desirable, if available. For example: 'referral' to an endocrinologist for diabetes management.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description about the service requested.

annotations.comment: This data point should be used to describe the named service in more detail, including how it should be delivered, patient concerns and issues that might be encountered in delivering the service.

localizedDescriptions.en: Description of the intent for the request.

annotations.comment: For example: a referral to a specialist may have the intent of the specialist taking over responsibility for care of the patient, or it may be to provide a second opinion on treatment options. Coding of the 'Intent' with a coding system is desirable, if available. This data element allows multiple occurrences to enable the user to record a multiple responses, if required.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date/time, or acceptable interval of date/time, for provision of the service.

annotations.comment: This data element allows for recording of the timing for a single service, either as a date and time, a date ranges or a text descriptor which can allow for 'next available. In practice, clinicians will often think in terms of ordering services as approximate timing, for example: review in 3 months, 6 months or 12 months. As clinical systems need more exact parameters to operate on, this '3 months' will usually be converted to an exact date 3 months from the date of recording and stored using this data element. If complex timing or sequences of timings are required, use the CLUSTER.service_direction archetype within the 'Complex timing' SLOT and this data element becomes redundant.

localizedDescriptions.en: Request for a health-related service or activity to be delivered by a clinician, organisation or agency.
Current Activity.
The name of the single service or activity requested.

annotations.comment: Coding of the 'Service name' with a coding system is desirable, if available. For example: 'referral' to an endocrinologist for diabetes management.

localizedDescriptions.en: An order for a medication, vaccine, nutritional product or other therapeutic item for an identified individual.
Details of the requested order.
Name of the medication, vaccine or other therapeutic/prescribable item being ordered.

annotations.comment: Depending on the prescribing context this field could be used for either generic- or product-based prescribing. This data field can be used to record tightly bound orders of different medications when they are prescribed as a single pack. It is strongly recommended that the 'Medication item' be coded with a terminology capable of triggering decision support, where possible. The extent of coding may vary from the simple name of the medication item through to structured details about the actual medication pack to be used. Free text entry should only be used if there is no appropriate terminology available.

localizedDescriptions.en: The route by which the ordered item is to be administered into the subject's body.

annotations.comment:
For example: 'oral', 'intravenous', or 'topical'.
Coding of the route with a terminology is preferred, where possible. Multiple potential routes may be specified.

localizedDescriptions.en: Complete narrative description about how the ordered item is to be used.

annotations.comment: This narrative should normally subsume data captured in 'Dose amount', 'Dose timing' and any additional instructions for use. Where the medication dose directions are fully carried by the structured, computable dose directions, this element should carry the narrative equivalent, generally auto-generated. If it is not possible to represent the intended 'Dose direction' fully in computable form, partial representation is not recommended, and the directions should be only recorded in narrative form using this data element.

localizedDescriptions.en: Structured details of a single therapeutic direction for an ordered item, such as a medication or blood transfusion order.
The combination of a medication amount and administration timing for a single day, in the context of a medication order or medication management.
Structured information about the intended timing of a therapeutic or diagnostic activity within any 24 hour period.
The frequency as number of times per time period that the activity is to take place.
The frequency as number of times per time period that the activity is to take place.

annotations.comment: For example: "4 times per day" or "3 to 4 times per hour".

localizedDescriptions.en: The frequency as number of times per time period that the activity is to take place.

annotations.comment: For example: "4 times per day" or "3 to 4 times per hour".
For example: "4 times per day" or "3 to 4 times per hour".

localizedDescriptions.en: Text description of the daily timing. This element is intended to allow implementers to use the structures for different timings without necessarily specifying the timings in a structured way.

annotations.comment: For example: "Take morning and evening".

For example: '2 tablets at 6pm' or '20mg three times per day'. Please note: this cluster allows multiple occurrences to enable representation of a complete set of dose patterns for a single dose direction.

localizedDescriptions.en: The length of time for which this direction should be applied.
The length of time for which this direction should be applied.
The direction should be continued indefinitely.
The direction should be continued indefinitely with a strong recommendation that it never be discontinued.

annotations.comment: For example: 'for 7 days','Indefinite'. An example of a set of multiple directions, with varying durations might be ... '1 tablet daily for 3 days, 2 tablets daily for 4 days, then 3 tablets Indefinite'.

localizedDescriptions.en: The length of time for which this direction should be applied.

annotations.comment: For example: 'for 7 days','Indefinite'. An example of a set of multiple directions, with varying durations might be ... '1 tablet daily for 3 days, 2 tablets daily for 4 days, then 3 tablets Indefinite'.

localizedDescriptions.en: The length of time for which this direction should be applied.

annotations.comment: For example: 'for 7 days','Indefinite'. An example of a set of multiple directions, with varying durations might be ... '1 tablet daily for 3 days, 2 tablets daily for 4 days, then 3 tablets Indefinite'.

For example: 'for 7 days','Indefinite'. An example of a set of multiple directions, with varying durations might be ... '1 tablet daily for 3 days, 2 tablets daily for 4 days, then 3 tablets Indefinite'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the medication order not captured in other fields.
The subjective clinical history of the subject of care as recorded directly by the subject, or reported to a clinician by the subject or a carer.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Narrative description of the story or clinical history for the subject of care.
Request for a health-related service or activity to be delivered by a clinician, organisation or agency.
Current Activity.
The name of the single service or activity requested.

annotations.comment: Coding of the 'Service name' with a coding system is desirable, if available. For example: 'referral' to an endocrinologist for diabetes management.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date/time, or acceptable interval of date/time, for provision of the service.

annotations.comment: This data element allows for recording of the timing for a single service, either as a date and time, a date ranges or a text descriptor which can allow for 'next available. In practice, clinicians will often think in terms of ordering services as approximate timing, for example: review in 3 months, 6 months or 12 months. As clinical systems need more exact parameters to operate on, this '3 months' will usually be converted to an exact date 3 months from the date of recording and stored using this data element. If complex timing or sequences of timings are required, use the CLUSTER.service_direction archetype within the 'Complex timing' SLOT and this data element becomes redundant.
